proper noun.description: An informal name for the southern states of the US.

phrases: until you nail down the facts, you're just whistling Dixie
Sharon rebuked him ever so slightly but is really whistling Dixie.
The board is whistling Dixie as it thinks it can summon up a contesting bid higher than $4.17 without showing a very sharp rise in recurrent earnings.
They ain't whistling Dixie when they say they don't make them like they used to.
Dean wasn't just whistling Dixie when he made his infamous remark about reaching out to bubbas bearing Confederate flags.
origin: Mid 19th century: origin uncertain. The phrase Dixie's land is first recorded in the 1859 minstrel song Jonny Roach, typically attributed to the minstrel performer Daniel D. Emmett. Emmett also wrote and performed I Wish I Was in Dixie later in the same year; this song, now known simply as Dixie, became enormously popular during the American Civil War and led to the association of the name with the American South.
